quote: Chief Medical Officer's log, Stardate    47529.4.  For the past week Chief    O'Brien and I have been helping    scientists from the Kellerun and    T'Lani races find a way to eliminate    their stockpile of Harvesters... a    deadly biomechanical gene disrupter    used by both sides in their centuries-   long war...
Doctor Nydrom, how's our muon charge?
Coming up to full power.
Computer... this is Harvester test    sequence three hundred and seventy-   five.
(still at control     station)   Muon generator now at full power.
Once more into the breech... I hope    this works, because frankly I'm    running out of ideas.
It took ten years to perfect the    Harvesters.  We've only been trying    to eliminate them for a week.
Is that all it's been?  It feels    like we've been working nonstop for    a month.  I've never seen a nano-   biogenic weapon so resistant to broad    spectrum radiation...
(eyeing muon bath;     thinking  out loud)   It's all a matter of finding the    right combination of muon    frequencies...       It should be simple... but it's    not...
(letting out some     tension)   Doctor, start the sequence... or    we will be here a month.
Right, Chief.       I'm introducing the Harvesters into    the genetic bath...
Beginning muon influx now...
Doctor, would you please check for    any gene-disrupter phasing...
The genetic integrity of the sample    is holding steady.  I'm not reading    any genetic disruption at all.
Are you sure?  Run the sequence    again...
(works panel; rechecks     readings)   The results are identical...
What?  Did it work?       Somebody say something... !
It worked all right...
The Harvesters have been destroyed.
Good news, I take it...
Ambassador Sharat.  I'm pleased to    inform you that we've found a way to    eliminate the Harvesters...

Excellent.  Well done.  I knew if    our people stopped killing each other    and worked together, we'd put an end    to these horrible weapons... this is    a symbol of the new future we have    embarked upon...
Yes.  And let's not forget, we never    could have done this without the    help of our friends from the    Federation...
At first we had questioned Doctor    Nydrom's decision to bring in outside    help.  But obviously it was the right    thing to do.  We're all grateful for    your assistance.
It was our pleasure, I assure you.
But eliminating the Harvesters is    only half the task.  We must make    certain that all scientific data    concerning them is wiped out as well.

I've purged every file in the T'Lani    and Kellerun data banks pertaining    to the Harvesters.  If anyone gets    it in their head to build these things    again, they'll have to start from    scratch.
Then it's finished.
Not quite...
We shouldn't rest until the entire    Kellerun and T'Lani supply of    Harvesters has been destroyed...
We'll begin immediately.
Commander, I have Doctor Bashir for    you on subspace.
In here.
Commander, we have some good news to    report...
I've already heard.
You have?
I received a message from both the    T'Lani and Kellerun ambassadors,    informing me of your success in    neutralizing the Harvesters.     Congratulations, gentlemen.
Thank you, sir.  The Doctor here    deserves the bulk of the credit.
Actually, it was a team effort...
The Doctor's just being modest.  He    was the one who came up with muon    rays as a possible solution.
Luckily, it worked.
When can we expect you back?
Soon, I hope.
The ambassadors said something about    a celebration on T'Lani Prime...
Yes... it's planned for tonight.     But the Chief is anxious to return    to the station.
(to Sisko; re: having     been with Bashir)   It's been a long week.
Still -- I think we can spare you    for another day...
I agree... if that's okay with you,    Chief.
I suppose another day won't kill    me...
That's the spirit.
Then we'll expect you back the day    after tomorrow.    (more for the Chief's     benefit)   Enjoy yourselves.  You've earned it.
The last cylinder... I believe you    should have the honor, Doctor.
My pleasure.

It's ironic that the war would finally    come to an end up here, above T'Lani    Three... a planet whose entire    population was decimated by the    Harvesters...       I hope this will be a lasting peace.
What is this?  You know weapons aren't    allowed in here...
They're all dead...
We will be, too, if we don't get out    of here...       O'Brien to Ganges.  Computer, activate    remote transporter sequence.
O'Brien to Ganges...
They must be jamming communications    with the runabout...
Well, we sure as hell can't stay    here.       We'll have to beam down to the    surface...
But they'll be able to follow us...
I'm programming the system to overload    thirty seconds after we transport...       Let's go...
I'll have a cup of Alterian chowder...    uttaberry crepes... and a slice of...
Kira to Sisko.
Go ahead, Major.
The T'Lani and Kellerun ambassadors    have just arrived on the station.     They're asking to see you.
Are O'Brien and Bashir with them?
No, Commander.  And the ambassadors    refuse to speak to anyone but you.
Show them to my office.  I'll be    right there.       I'll have to cancel that order.
Are you saying both of my officers    are dead?
(nods sadly; speaks     for both Sharat and     herself)   Along with some of our greatest    scientists.
We're sorry you have to share in our    misfortune.
What happened?
It was...

... a terrible accident.  It appears    one of your officers -- Chief O'Brien,    I believe -- inadvertently tripped a    security device.  A lethal pulse of    radiation flooded the room, killing    everyone...
Ambassador Sharat transported off    the ship only minutes before the    accident occurred.
(wanting more     information)   This security device...
It was built into the lab's computers    decades ago... we didn't even know    it existed.
(trying to make sense     of it)   If there were no survivors, how do    you know Chief O'Brien caused the    accident?
I was able to return to the ship    almost immediately after the accident.
The first thing I did was to check    the internal security sensors.  They    recorded the entire incident.    (hands Sisko a data     clip)   We assumed you'd want to see for    yourself.
Thank you.
Commander, I just want you to know    we don't blame Chief O'Brien for    what happened...
On the contrary, both he and Doctor    Bashir will always be considered    heroes to both the T'Lani and the    Kelleruns.  Without their help, we    would never have destroyed the    Harvesters.
Please extend our sympathies to their    families.
I'll do that.
Chief!  Chief, in here!
Wait.  Don't touch anything...
Why not?  There's food, medical    supplies...

They could be booby-trapped.  The    Cardassians used to rig the supplies    they left behind with pressure    grenades.  I've seen more than one    soldier permanently lose his appetite    that way...
Find anything?
It looks all right...
Good.
At least we won't starve...
What's the matter, Chief?  I thought    you loved military rations...
Federation rations.  I've had enough    T'Lani food this past week to last    me a lifetime...
Still, you want to keep your strength    up.  We're going to have to find    some way to warn the T'Lani's that    the Kelleruns have broken the    treaty...
I still can't figure it -- why would    the Kelleruns wait until the    Harvesters were destroyed before    they made their move?
Maybe they didn't turn over all of    their Harvesters for destruction...
Or maybe they're convinced they can    defeat the T'Lani with conventional    weapons.
Whatever the reason, we need to get    moving.

Listen to me, Julian... the Kelleruns    are going to expect us to be on the    move... we start running and their    sensors will pick us up before we've    gone a kilometer.  If we stay still...    maybe, just maybe it will take them    longer to find us...
The way I see it, we have only one    chance to survive this thing... that's    to stay alive long enough for    Commander Sisko to find us.
But that won't be for at least another    day... he thinks we're celebrating    on T'Lani Prime...
I said it was our only chance, I    didn't say it was a good one.
What do we have here?       Some kind of com system... maybe we    can contact the T'Lani from here...
You think you can get it working?
I'll have to open it up... see if    there's a backup power supply...
Why don't you have a seat, Doctor?
I thought maybe I could help... I    took the engineering extension courses    at Starfleet Medical...
Extension courses... ?
They were actually quite    informative...
Julian...
Hmmm?
You really want to help?
Yes.
Then let me do my job.
Of course.       I'll inventory the supplies.
(already starting to     work)   Fine... you do that...
The last cylinder... I believe you    should have the honor, Doctor.
My pleasure.
(as before, a     pronouncement)   The Harvesters have been destroyed.
We must make certain that all records    of their existence are wiped out.

I've purged every file in the T'Lani    and Kellerun data banks pertaining    to the Harvesters.  If anyone gets    it in their head to build these things    again, they'll have to start from    scratch.
Then it's finished.
Hold on... what's this?
Chief... ?

I don't know.  Closing the last file    seems to have activated some sort of    security program...    (starts working the     panel)   It looks like it's part of the    original operating system... I can't    shut it down.       You know anything about this?
No... maybe you should try cutting    the power...
It's not responding...
I've heard of security weapons like    this.  A radiation pulse that    vaporizes any intruder who doesn't    enter the proper code.
I'm surprised the Chief didn't detect    it.
It must've been buried very deep in    the system.
I'd like to talk to the head of    security for that ship...
So would I.
Remember, they lost people, too.
But the T'Lani were responsible for    O'Brien's and Bashir's safety...    they should have known about that    device and deactivated it...

That'll do, Major.    (knowing there's     nothing to do but go     on)   Major, I'd like you to get in touch    with Bajoran medical officials.     We'll need a doctor to be temporarily    assigned to the station... until    Starfleet can send us a replacement    for Doctor Bashir...
Dax, inform Starfleet about the    accident... tell them we'll need a    new medical officer and a new chief    of operations.
Would you like me to go with you to    see Mrs. O'Brien?

No, I'll take care of it.  Find out    how I can get in contact with Julian's    family...       Major, inform the crew we'll be    holding a memorial service tomorrow    evening at eighteen hundred hours.
Yes, sir.
All right, people.  I know the next    few days are going to be hard.  But    we all have jobs to do.
So... having any luck?
(pauses again; getting     frustrated)   I wish you'd stop asking me that...
I'm sorry, it's just... all this    standing around... at least you're    doing something constructive...
Just keep your eyes open for any    Kellerun soldiers...
Don't worry, I will.
It's a real mess in here...
You'll get it working, Chief.  This    is the kind of challenge you live    for...
You know, I was really looking forward    to that celebration on T'Lani Prime...    I don't know if you've noticed, but    the T'Lani women are quite    attractive...
I'm not blind, Julian.
Of course not.       But you are married.
Just because you're married doesn't    mean you stop looking at women.
As long as you don't let your wife    see you look.       For me, tonight's celebration would    have been an adventure.  The most    you could have hoped for was... a    good meal.
Women.  That's all you ever think    about...
No, it isn't...       Though I do think about them a lot.
Just wait until you fall in love    with one.
I did once.
Didn't work out?
Close.  Not quite.  I don't know.     Somehow marriage doesn't seem fair...
Fair?
Fair to them.  I mean look at us...    Our lives are constantly in danger.     There's enough to worry about without    worrying about the wife and kids    back home worrying about us.
Sorry, Chief.  That's the way I feel.     It's the way a lot of career officers    feel.
Well, all of you "career officers"    have no idea what you're missing.
Really?  Well, maybe so.  But I look    at you and Mrs. O'Brien and I...
What about "me and Mrs. O'Brien?"
Nothing.
What?
Nothing.  Absolutely nothing.    (finally, off O'Brien's     look)   It's no secret that being assigned    to the station hasn't been conducive    to your marriage.
Say that again?
Let's just forget the whole thing.
That's the first intelligent thing    you've said since we got here...
Are you cold?
Aren't you?
No.  In fact, it's quite warm in    here...
You're looking a little pale...
I'm fine...
Your blood pressure's low... and    you're running a fever... you better    sit down.
I don't feel like sitting down.     I've got work to do...
Roll up your sleeve.
Why?
Just do it.
You were behind the genetic bath    when it shattered, weren't you...
(reacting to Bashir's     serious expression)   If you've got something to tell me,    Doctor...
You've been infected by the    Harvesters...
Come in.
Commander Sisko...
Keiko.
Something's happened to Miles...
There was an accident...
Both your husband and Doctor Bashir    were involved...
They're dead...
I'm sorry.
Tell me what happened.
The T'Lani security sensors recorded    the entire incident.
I want to see it.
I'll have it sent to you.       Miles was a fine officer and a fine    man.  I'll miss him.
Thank you, Commander.  I'd like to    be alone now.
If there's anything you need, just    let me know.
Damn T'Lani circuitry...       The way they have everything packed    in here...
Let me take a look at that...
I'm fine, Doctor... go back to your    post...
Look, Chief... about you and Mrs.    O'Brien... I didn't mean to imply...
I'm trying to work here, Doctor...
Maybe you should rest a bit...
I'm fine.  Just give me another one    of those anabolic supplements.
Ahhh, that's better.
Chief... ?
It's my eyes... getting a little    fuzzy...
You better sit down.  I'll take over    here.
What makes you think you can fix    this thing?
Because you're going to talk me    through it.  Now have a seat...
Maybe just for a minute...
... or two...
All right, Chief... tell me where    you left off...
Do you see that dark blue coil in    the upper right hand corner?
No.
It's right next to the green    cylinder...    (remembering; seeing     it in his mind)   Behind it a little bit...
Yes, I see it.
You have to lock the base of the    coil into that tiny receptor right    below it...
You know, I just remembered... I    still have Julian's medical school    diaries...
He let you read them?
He felt they would make me understand    him better.
How?  By reading about all the women    he went out with?

They're not about that.  When he    gave them to me, he told me they    were about his innermost thoughts...    his struggle to graduate at the top    of his class... his dreams of a career    in Starfleet... his constant fear of    failure...
Really.  And did you understand him    better?
I never got around to reading them...
I suppose I should send them to his    parents.
You could keep them...
Really?
I think he'd like that.  He... cared    about you a great deal.
I know.  I cared about him, too.
(respectful of the     moment)   These are on the house.
How come?
I thought we'd have a toast to the    memory of Chief O'Brien and Doctor    Bashir.
That's very thoughtful, Quark...
(looks at a doubting     Kira)   I can be thoughtful.

To our dear departed comrades... we    may have had our differences, but    I'll say this for them -- and there's    no higher tribute I can think of...       They were good customers.  They always    paid their bar bills on time.
That's it?
I'm not done yet.       At times like these I'm reminded of    the Fifty-Seventh Rule of Acquisition:    "Good customers are as rare as latinum --    treasure them."
(surprised at Keiko's     presence in OPS)   Mrs. O'Brien... ?
Major, I have to see Commander Sisko.     It's important.
I'll tell him you're here.    (before she alerts     Sisko)   I just want you to know how sorry I    am...       ... how sorry we all are...
Thank you.
Watch -- it's coming up in just a    few seconds --
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: ... If anyone gets it in their head    to build these things again, they'll    have to start from scratch.
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: Then it's finished.
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: Computer, freeze image.
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: There.  Do you see it?
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: I see the Chief drinking coffee...
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: Exactly.  Now, look at the time index.
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: Fifteen hundred hours...
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: That's right.  Late afternoon.       Miles never drank coffee in the    afternoon.  It kept him up all night.
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: Maybe he made an exception this time.     He was working long hours, under a    lot of stress...
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: I know my husband.  He never drank    coffee that late in the day.
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: Maybe he's not drinking coffee.       Maybe it's tea...
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: I checked the data clip and it    contained a spectroscopic analysis.     The liquid in Miles' cup consisted    of vegetable-based oils and    caffeine... it's coffee all right...
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: (exploring the     possibility)   You're saying this recording has    been tampered with...
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: Yes, I am.  And I'd like to know the    reason why.
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: When were you planning on bringing    the Ganges back from T'Lani Three?
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: Tomorrow.
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: I don't see any reason to wait, do    you?
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: I'll leave right away.
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: Good.  I'll come with you.       Mrs. O'Brien... if this recording    has been altered, we'll find out    why.
scene: 38   INT. COMMANDER'S OFFICE - TIGHT ON MONITOR (OPTICAL)

quote: You were right, Chief... the contacts    on the subprocessor are corroded...
They need to be cleaned...
I think there's some sterile pads in    the med kit...
Here we go.
Stay with me, Chief... I still need    your help...
Don't worry... I'm not going    anywhere...
Who was she?
Who... ?
"Close.  Not quite."
Palis.  Palis Delon.  She was a    dancer.  A ballerina.  She had    exquisite feet...

I'm serious... it's very important    for a dancer to have good arches...       She was gorgeous... not to mention    brilliant... I'd watch her on stage...    I couldn't believe anyone could be    that graceful...
And she was crazy about you...
We were crazy about each other.  I    thought, "Julian, you lucky devil --    you've found the perfect woman."  We    used to finish each other's    thoughts...
What do you think?
Good.  Now put it back in the panel...
Looks like we have some power    anyway...
Still no response from the    transmitter...
Try retuning the R-F oscillator...
So what happened?    (off Bashir's     questioning look)   With you and Palis?

What happened is I graduated... her    father was the top administrator for    a medical complex in Paris... he    offered me a job there... promised    I'd be chief of surgery within five    years...
But that meant giving up your career    in Starfleet...
You have no idea how close I came...       But... here I am...
You made your choice...
Yes... though sometimes I wake up in    the middle of the night and I think    to myself... will I ever find anyone    that wonderful again... ?
The oscillator's working, but the    frequency's still fluctuating...
Let me take a look at it...
What is it?
My legs... hard to move...    (beat; looks up at     Bashir)   I can't feel them anymore...
We're approaching T'Lani Three.     Establishing a synchronous orbit    along side the Ganges.
scene: 45   INT. RUNABOUT RIO GRANDE - IN MOTION

quote: Open a channel to the T'Lani cruiser.
scene: 45   INT. RUNABOUT RIO GRANDE - IN MOTION

quote: Commander Sisko -- what a pleasant    surprise.  I take it you're here for    your runabout...
scene: 45   INT. RUNABOUT RIO GRANDE - IN MOTION

quote: That's right.
scene: 45   INT. RUNABOUT RIO GRANDE - IN MOTION

quote: We were about to leave for the    memorial service on T'Lani Prime.     You're welcome to accompany us...
scene: 45   INT. RUNABOUT RIO GRANDE - IN MOTION

quote: Perhaps we will.  But first I'd like    to see for myself where the accident    took place...
scene: 45   INT. RUNABOUT RIO GRANDE - IN MOTION

quote: Of course.
scene: 45   INT. RUNABOUT RIO GRANDE - IN MOTION

quote: While you're on the cruiser, I think    I'll beam over to the Ganges and    take a look around.
scene: 45   INT. RUNABOUT RIO GRANDE - IN MOTION

quote: Good idea.
scene: 45   INT. RUNABOUT RIO GRANDE - IN MOTION

quote: Chief... Chief!  It's working...    (continues working     the panel)   The signal's very faint...
You'll have to shift... to a higher    carrier frequency... go back into    the companel... reset the actuators...    on the chambers coil...
That's better... it's still pretty    weak though...
I'm sending a distress signal.  I've    set it to repeat every two minutes...       Let's hope the T'Lani find us before    the Kellerun do.
They better get here soon...
Don't worry, Chief... I'm going to    get you home...
In a box, maybe...
(forcing himself to     be optimistic)   Nonsense.  Don't go giving up on me    now...
I'm not giving up... I'm dying...    listen to me, Julian... you have to    tell Keiko and Molly...
You'll tell them yourself...
You know, you're wrong... about    marriage.
Whatever you say, Chief.

Listen to me, Julian.  You're always    talking about adventure... well    marriage is the greatest adventure    of all.  It's filled with pitfalls    and setbacks and mistakes, but it's    a journey worth taking... because    you take it together.

I know Keiko's been unhappy... about    our coming to the station... we still    argue about it... But that's all    right... because at the end of the    day, we both know we love each other.     And when you get right down to it,    that's all that matters.
You'd better get some rest.  The    T'Lani should be here soon...
I see there's still residual traces    of the radiatiopulse...
That's to be expected, given the    pulse's intensity.  But it poses no    danger.
Tell me, Ambassador -- have you been    able to learn more about the fail-   safe device that caused the accident?
Not yet, Commander, but we're working    on it...
It was Ambassador Sharat who brought    you the data clip...
That's right.
I suppose he showed it to you as    soon as you arrived...
Of course.
Could the clip have been altered    before you saw it?
Why would Ambassador Sharat alter    the data clip?
I have no idea.
Sisko.
Commander, when you're through there,    could you join me on the Ganges?
I'll only be a few more minutes.
Commander, the T'Lani and Kellerun    have finally made peace.  That peace    cannot survive unless both sides    trust each other...
What've you got, Dax?
It looks like someone has erased    five seconds from the Ganges's computer    log --
Show me.
At first I thought it was just some    kind of power fluctuation... but    when I checked the log's memory core,    it showed traces of a remote transport    command...
Did you find any indication of    transporter activity at that time?
No.
And you're saying somebody erased it    later on...
(nods, then gestures     at monitor)   Look at the time index when the call    for transport came in...
At fifteen thirty four... that's a    full three minutes after the accident    on the T'Lani cruiser.
Which means if either Chief O'Brien    or Julian made that request...
... they would've been alive after    the fail-safe device went off...
Good work, Lieutenant.
Come on, Chief... don't leave me...    breathe... !
That's it... you're doing it...
Tell me, Julian... you ever talk to    that ballerina of yours... ?
Not since I left Earth...
Maybe you should...
Maybe one day I will.
Ambassador E'Tyshra... am I glad to    see you.  Chief O'Brien was infected    by the Harvesters when the Kelleruns    attacked your ship... they killed    all of the scientists...
Not all of them...
You're too late, Sharat...
No, Doctor -- he's right on time.
But why kill Nydrom and the others?
To ensure that the peace agreement    between our two races will last.
But we'd already destroyed the    Harvesters... there was no need for    more killing... unless...
It's not enough to simply destroy    the Harvesters.  We have to make    sure no one can ever recreate them.
The only way to do that... was to    eliminate everyone who possessed    such knowledge...       ... including the two of you.
But we have no use for such a horrible    weapon...
As long as the knowledge exists,    there's a danger it may be used.     That's a risk we refuse to live with.
I truly am sorry, Doctor... but at    least you have the consolation of    knowing your deaths will be for a    noble cause.
The T'Lani and Kellerun soldiers    have their weapons trained on    Bashir...
scene: 57   INT. MILITARY COMMAND CENTER - CONTINUOUS ACTION

quote: Wait...
scene: 57   INT. MILITARY COMMAND CENTER - CONTINUOUS ACTION

quote: Let him speak.
scene: 57   INT. MILITARY COMMAND CENTER - CONTINUOUS ACTION

quote: Help me up... want to die... on my    feet...
scene: 57   INT. MILITARY COMMAND CENTER - CONTINUOUS ACTION

quote: I'm sorry I couldn't get us home,    Chief...
scene: 57   INT. MILITARY COMMAND CENTER - CONTINUOUS ACTION

quote: Did... best you could... been an    honor... serving with you...
scene: 57   INT. MILITARY COMMAND CENTER - CONTINUOUS ACTION

quote: Thank you, Chief... that means a lot    to...
scene: 57   INT. MILITARY COMMAND CENTER - CONTINUOUS ACTION

quote: Commander... am I glad to see you...
Chief O'Brien will be dead within an    hour unless we get him back to the    station...
What happened?
He was exposed to the Harvesters...
That should keep him stabilized for    a while...
They told us you were both dead,    Julian...
We would have been, if the T'Lani    and Kellerun had their way... they're    killing everyone involved with the    Harvester project.
The T'Lani cruiser's coming this    way... they're hailing us...
Ignore them... send out a general    distress signal on all Federation    subspace frequencies.
They're blocking all subspace    communications with a broad band    inversion.       They're hailing us again.
Is the inversion field affecting    sensors as well?
All short range sensors are useless...
Which means... theirs are useless    too...
Ambassador, Commander Sisko is    attempting to escape... we are in    pursuit...
Can we overtake them?
Their runabout is no match for this    ship.       Fire a warning shot.
Confirmed...       Commander Sisko is hailing us...
I thought he would.
By firing on this vessel, you've    committed an act of war against the    Federation.
Commander, we have no quarrel with    the Federation or with you... but we    must insist you turn over Doctor    Bashir and Chief O'Brien.
Why?  So you can murder them?
Unfortunately, Commander, your    officers are the only two people    left who have seen the data concerning    the development of the Harvesters.
They have no intention of ever using    that knowledge.  You have my word...
Their intentions are irrelevant.     The fact is, the threat remains as    long as the knowledge exists...
I know this is painful for you,    Commander.  It wasn't easy for us to    order the deaths of our own people.     But it is necessary...
And if I refuse to turn them over?
You can't outrun us and you can't    fight us.  We can destroy your    runabout at any time.
But Lieutenant Dax and I know nothing    about the Harvesters... are you    willing to kill us, too?
We'll do whatever we have to do to    ensure our safety...
Commander... you're running out of    options... you have one minute to    turn over Doctor Bashir and Chief    O'Brien...
You want them?  You're going to have    to take us all...
He leaves us no choice...
The runabout is turning... it's    heading back in our direction...
Full stop.
He's preparing to fire.
Employ shields.
Shields employed.
Put the runabout on screen.
He must know his phasers can't hurt    us...
He's aimed his vessel straight for    us.
The man must be crazy.
Fire phasers.
It's over.
Head back to T'Lani Three.  Prepare    to take the other runabout in tow.
Ambassador... sensors indicate the    other runabout is no longer in    orbit...
Then where is it?
I don't know... It's gone.
It can't just have disappeared.
I'm picking up a warp signature.
Sisko... Maybe he and the others    weren't on that runabout we destroyed.
They could have transported to the    other runabout while our sensors    were down.
And then piloted the first ship by    remote navigation.
But we saw them die.
Did we?
What's this?
Something Molly made for you.  She    painted it herself.
It's lovely.  She's got real talent...
How's my patient?
Better.  Can I go home now?
You should be out of here by tomorrow.       I want you to know, I really    appreciated what you said back on    T'Lani Three.
What did I say?
That it was an honor serving with    me...
Oh... right.

I'd like to return the compliment,    Chief -- it's been an honor to serve    with you, too.       You know, Mrs. O'Brien -- they say    when two people face death together,    it creates a bond that can never be    broken... I never believed that    until...
(starting to get     annoyed)   Julian...
Hmm?       Oh, yes -- of course.  You want to    be alone.  I understand.
(re:  O'Brien's     expression)   He saved your life, you know.
And he's never going to let me forget    it.
So what was it like... spending all    that time alone with him?
(good-natured     exasperation)   It was... hell.  You can see for    yourself -- the man never stops    talking.
You know, I wouldn't mind a cup of    coffee right now...
Miles -- you never drink coffee in    the afternoon --
Sure I do.
You do?
